author: @coreyms
text: Hey everyone. Hope you're all having a great weekend. I'm still working on finishing up the series. Let me know if there is anything specific you want me to cover. In the next video I'll be covering sorting, and some videos still to come include: working with dates, aggregating data, reading and writing to/from different sources, and a discussion on the recent Pandas version 1.0 release. Let me know if there is anything else you'd like to see! Thanks and have a good one!

author: @LB-qr7nv
text: Probably there is only an inplace-parameter if only the affected data (or not much more) gets changed. Append for example probably uses the numpy append which is not inplace, so all the data must be copied. For drop no time-consuming changes need to be done, just one key and pointer get removed

author: @fet1612
text: inplace=False <== (by default) video timestamp at Data School https://youtu.be/XaCSdr7pPmY?t=240 <<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>> dropna is removing a chunk of information from the DataFrame, hence is this precautionary measure of "inplace=False" Default in order to prevent any accidental deletions to take effect.       df.dropna(inplace=False) https://youtu.be/XaCSdr7pPmY?t=240

author: @fet1612
text: 11:55 @Corey's_students:  Follow the video reference of the "inplace" parameter. "inplace=False" is a "fail_safe" design. We can fiddle with the code, and when we're sure we want to make changes to the DataFrame permanently, we make the amendment.  We can then set "inplace=True". Here is a reference to a Data School video. No offense. We learn from each other. This is how knowledge grows. A good scientist is always learning. https://youtu.be/XaCSdr7pPmY?t=131

author: @fet1612
text: 7:50 append() df.append({'first' : 'Tony'}, ignore_index=True) <<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>> Corey_says: ignore_index <== set that equal to True. (( TypeError: Can only append a Series if ignore_index=True or if the Series has a name ))
